repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: vim.treesitter.goto_node() moves the cursor to the given node. Optional arguments include the window id in which to move the cursor (defaulting to the current window) and a (row, col) offset from the node's starting position.

comment_regular_data.body: Can't that be used in `:InspectTree` (which also sets the cursor to the current node in the tree view)?
No, because the playground object (or whatever we are calling it these days) does not store the node objects directly, just their metadata (e.g. `id`, position, etc.).
Hmm, this reduces the value of this new function somewhat... Do you have a concrete use case for it?

To explain where I'm coming from: We put the brakes on upstreaming nvim-treesitter utility functions for a reason, as it was turning into something of a grab bag without a clear vision for an API. And I suspect this will just be the first of more to come (back) -- like `swap_nodes`. So I'd like to start with a plan for `vim.treesitter.util` before adding such functions (which I'm not against in principle; rather the opposite) one by one.

> Do you have a concrete use case for it?

Any Treesitter-based (re)implementation of something like matchit, or the builtin (and sub-par) `[[` or `[m` style motions, would be able to use this.

For myself, I have "context" Treesitter queries that I use to show the current function signature in a floating window (similar to `nvim-treesitter-context`, but homebrewed). I would use this to make a "move to next/previous context" mapping. I also use this in my own "swap function arguments" Treesitter plugin.

I understand the concern about adding functions willy nilly with the justification "maybe this could be useful", but I do think that this function in particular passes the bar, since  cursor movement is such a fundamentally useful and common action.

OK, a treesitter aware `matchit` replacement _is_ something that is in scope. But still, even given that this function is worth having, we could think about the best way of structuring these functions -- not necessarily as a submodule, but e.g. by better naming conventions. (The only better time than for this than "now" is "yesterday"...)

Personally I do feel this is a bit too low value to be adding a specific function for and IMO doesn't really justify the additional surface area. The `offset` option also seems particularly weird to me.

Plenty of uses in the wild, it's not exactly a niche feature: https://github.com/search?q=goto_node%28+language%3ALua+&type=code

If we want Treesitter to stop using `nvim-treesitter` as a basic dependency for everything, we need to move some of these fundamental utilities into core.

Yes, but hopefully in a more structured and sustainable manner ;)

To be clear: we definitely want (and have started work) to remove nvim-treesitter as a "treesitter standard library", so we need to put our money where our mouth is in some form. What's needed is 

1. a sort of triage process (does this need to be in core, or is it not too much to ask for plugins/users just to implement this themselves) -- ideally one that does _not_ boil down to "I feel it should" vs. "I feel it shouldn't";

2. a sort of vision how we want that standard library to look long(ish)-term.

I don't care whether the answer to 2. is a `vim.ts.utils` or not (although I personally prefer a smaller module to the whole namespace becoming a "dustbin with little coherence", but that's just me).

One step in this direction could be to make `node` a first class object like `query` and `language` and structure this (and related functions) around `node.verb()`.

> Yes, but hopefully in a more structured and sustainable manner ;)

I guess that's subjective, personally I don't want to see a `vim.treesitter.utils` appear. `utils` modules inevitably become dustbins with little to no coherency or thoughtfulness.

Having a large, flat module namespace doesn't bother me, so I don't really share your concerns here.

> Plenty of uses in the wild, it's not exactly a niche feature: [github.com/search?q=goto_node%28+language%3ALua+&type=code](https://github.com/search?q=goto_node%28+language%3ALua+&type=code)

There are quite a lot of duplicates and false-positives out of the 115 matches. It's mostly nvim-treesitter, navigator.lua, neorg and splitjoin.nvim.

> If we want Treesitter to stop using nvim-treesitter as a basic dependency for everything, we need to move some of these fundamental utilities into core.

We have been. I'm just not convinced this one should make the cut.

>a sort of triage process (does this need to be in core, or is it not too much to ask for plugins/users just to implement this themselves) -- ideally one that does not boil down to "I feel it should" vs. "I feel it shouldn't";

Agreed.

The argument in favor of `goto_node()` is that:

1. Cursor movement is a fundamental operation in Neovim
2. TS nodes are fundamental data types in Treesitter
3. Therefore, the ability to move the cursor to a node is a fundamentally useful thing to do and should have first class support

> ideally one that does not boil down to "I feel it should" vs. "I feel it shouldn't";

I think two decent - although still somewhat subjective- metrics are:

- depth (a deep and complex function)
- composability with other functions

> I don't want to see a vim.treesitter.utils appear. utils modules inevitably become dustbins with little to no coherency or thoughtfulness.

+1

--- 

Regarding the concrete `goto_node`. No strong opinion, just my 2 cents:

- I also find the offset special case a bit odd.
- I get the impression that we've in general a bit of poor composability in regards to functions that work with positions or ranges but I've no idea how to fix it. In the LSP area we've (0,0) indexed Position with line and character and Range with a start and end Position. window cursor is usually (1, 0) indexed. Some APIs have separate line and column parameters, others work with tuples. It's the wild west and a lot of logic is about going from one representation to another while avoiding the dreaded off by one error.  :/
If we add new convenience functions to go from one to another I think it might be worth zooming out a bit to see if there could be a more generalised solution that could cover non-treesitter cases as well

By that argument, so would `highlight_node()`? (I guess what I'm saying is that non-triviality of the implementation needs to be part of the argument.)

And ðŸ’¯ on @mfussenegger's point on composability. That is precisely what I've been missing -- from nvim-treesitter already -- without being able to put my finger on it. A more full-featured `vim.range` with conversion functions would already go a long way. (Or an actual, first-class, `Range` object that is API-agnostic, which every API has input and output converters for -- and maybe overloads `+` to allow for offsets or somesuch.)

Another, related, point is discoverability: one reason people tend to request custom APIs is that they don't realize how simple they often are to implement, as they don't know what all is available and how -- or even that -- the different APIs (here: treesitter, nvim, basic Lua) interact.

Once you remove the boilerplate you are effectively left with:

```lua
local buf = api.nvim_win_get_buf(winid)
local row, col = unpack(vim.treesitter.get_range(node, buf, metadata))
api.nvim_win_set_cursor(winid, { row + 1, col })
```

So it isn't providing much technically or as an abstraction, and thus the value proposition is low.

Additionally, I could imagine variations of this where `goto_node` wouldn't fit, so using the lower level API's seems generally preferable IMO.

> If we add new convenience functions to go from one to another I think it might be worth zooming out a bit to see if there could be a more generalised solution that could cover non-treesitter cases as well

Just to mention, treesitter has 2 different notations for a nodes location:
- `row, col, end_row, end_col`
- `row, col, byte, end_row, end_col, end_byte`.

Internally we tend to use byte locations since that is more precise and what treesitter itself uses since parsing is generally `\n` agnostic.

>Why doesn't vim.fn.cursor(node:start()) (plus win_execute()) work, and what is needed to make something like that work?

Partly the different position representations that have already been mentioned (1 based row vs 0 based row), but also because a node can contain metadata set by a directive in a query that can modify its position, so we also need a way to handle that (see @lewis6991's example above).

Closing since we don't have agreement that this is worth having in core.

We don't have agreement (yet) because we haven't finished the discussion...

I think there's agreement that this should be easy to do out-of-the-box, just not yet what the best way to do it is.

(In general, I'd hope for such discussions to be more constructive and solution-oriented and less dismissive and "stone-walling". The question should be "what do we need to make this -- and similar functionality -- achievable in two lines?)

I'd be in favor of any of these directions:

- add a function `vim.goto()` (`vim.cursor()`?) which accepts `TSNode` (and could later accept other "position" forms)
    - this assumes that we will eventually need `vim.goto()` _anyways_. If we're sure that the existing `cursor()` is enough to avoid `vim.goto()` in the long term, then no objection to `vim.treesitter.goto()`.
- add `TSNode` support to `cursor()` (weird, but avoids a new function)

At minimum, we should definitely document the current "state of the art", because it's not 100% obvious.

I probably missed some, but I think these are the cursor/position related functions:

- `vim.region(..., pos1, pos2, ...)`
    - pos1 & pos2: `integer[] (line, column)` `(0,0)` indexed byte positions
- `vim.inspect_pos(..., row, col, ...)` 0 based
- `vim.show_pos(..., row, col, ...)` 0 based

- `vim.highlight.range(... start, finish, ...)` - `{line, col}` tuple, doesn't mention if `(0, 0)` or something else?

- `vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, ...)`
- `vim.fn.cursor(lnum, col, off)` `(1, 1)` - With `0` meaning stay in current line or column
- `vim.fn.getpos(expr)` - result is `[bufnr, lnum, col, off]` (1, 1) based;
- `vim.fn.getcurpos([{winid}])` like ^ but with an extra `curswant` in the result.
- `vim.fn.getline(lnum, end)` - 1 based
- `nvim_win_set_cursor(win, pos)` -  `pos` is `(row, col)` tuple  with `(1, 0)` indexing
- `nvim_win_get_cursor(win)` - Mirrors `nvim_win_set_cursor`
- `nvim_buf_get_lines(..., start, end, ...)` - 0 based, end-exclusive
- `nvim_buf_get_lines(..., start_row, start_col, end_row, end_col...)` - 0 based, row indices end-inclusive, column indices end-exclusive


LSP structures:

```
Position
   line: integer 0 based
   character: integer 0 base  (but encoding dependent
```

```
Range
    start: Position
    end: Position
```

---

What would be the advantage of a `vim.cursor()` or `vim.goto()`? That it is also `(0, 0)` based?

I kinda like the idea of the `Range` class @clason mentioned, but I don't see how we could integrate that with the existing functions.

@mfussenegger nice list, ~~let's put that in an issue!~~ (Edit: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25509 )

> What would be the advantage of a `vim.cursor()` or `vim.goto()`? That it is also `(0, 0)` based?

What are the current steps need to goto a position represented by TSNode? Shouldn't it be as easy as: `vim.cursor(node:pos())` ?

An intermediary `Position` (can `Range` represent a single point...?) object, can be interchanged amongst all the functions you listed, without the caller needing to patch things up.

> Shouldn't it be as easy as: vim.cursor(node:pos()) ?

A node has two positions, start and end, so this would need to be `vim.cursor(node:start_pos())` or `vim.cursor(node:end_pos())`

title: feat(treesitter): implement goto_node()
